general: This act helps simplify the legal system by getting rid of laws that are no longer useful or needed. It looks at laws passed in the past and decides which ones can be removed because they are not important anymore. This makes the legal system more efficient and easier to understand.

series.short: "Reforming Legislation: Streamlining Enactments and Instruments Across Territories"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: Repeals certain enactments and revokes related instruments.
* Simplified point 2: Provides for consequential and connected provisions.
* Simplified point 3: Exempts certain provisions from being considered for reform under the Regulatory Reform Act.
* Simplified point 4: Extends to Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man, with Her Majesty having the power to extend the Act to other territories through Order in Council.
* Simplified point 5: Does not affect the law of countries outside the UK and IoM, except as modified by an order under subsection (3).

summary: The Statute Law (Repeals) Act 2004 helps improve the laws in the United Kingdom by getting rid of old laws that are no longer useful. This act repeals certain laws and revokes related documents, making way for new laws that are more helpful to society. The act also ensures that any changes made to existing laws are properly taken care of. Additionally, the act applies to Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man, allowing the monarch to expand its reach to other areas through an official decree. Overall, this act simplifies and modernizes the legal system in the UK, making it easier for everyone to follow and understand.
single:
• The Statute Law (Repeals) Act 2004 aims to simplify and modernize the statute law by repealing certain enactments that are no longer practical or useful.
• The Act repeals a list of enactments specified in Schedule 1, which includes laws related to various topics such as taxation, local government, and transportation.
• The repeal of these enactments does not affect any provision that has been amended within the past two years.
• The Act extends to Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man, and Her Majesty may provide for the repeal to extend to any of the Channel Islands or British overseas territories.
• The Act does not repeal or amend any enactment that forms part of the law of a country outside the United Kingdom and the Isle of Man.
• The Act may be cited as the Statute Law (Repeals) Act 2004.
